elements.content: Rare earth fluoride carbonates have been proven to be potential deep-ultraviolet optical materials, but lacked the systematic study on phase stability domains to guide synthesis. In this work, detailed investigations of the Na2CO3–GdF3–H2O system have been done in subcritical hydrothermal conditions. A series of sodium-rare earth carbonates crystals NaGdCO3F2 (1), Na2GdCO3F3 (2), Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3), and Na3Gd­(CO3)3·6H2O (4) have been synthesized. NaGdCO3F2 (1) is composed of a three-dimensional (3-D) [GdCO3F2]− framework with Na+ as the charge balance cation. Na2GdCO3F3 (2) showed two-dimensional (2-D) [GdCO3F3]2– layers along the c-axis and further bridged by Na+ to form a 3-D framework. Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3) is made up of alternately stacked layers [Na­(CO3)2]∞ along the a-axis and [Na2Gd­(CO3)2]∞ in the bc plane, forming a 3-D framework. Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O (4) exhibits an intricate 3-D structure composed of a [Gd­(CO3)3­(H2O)3]3– complex and bridging Na+ ions. The results from the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy study indicated that the short-wavelength absorption edge of all four compounds were below 200 nm, suggesting that they are potential deep-ultraviolet optical materials. Powder second harmonic generation measurements indicated that the compounds 3 and 4 are phase-matchable (type I), and they exhibit relatively strong second harmonic generation responses of approximately 3 and 2 times that of KH2PO4 (KDP).

elements.content: Deep-ultraviolet (DUV), nonlinear optical (NLO) materials, the key components of solid-state lasers producing DUV coherent light through a cascaded frequency conversion, have gained increasing attention owing to their versatile scientific and technological applications such as angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, laser-cooling, super-high-resolution, and semiconductor photolithography. Even though a few DUV NLO crystals have been reported in recent years, it still presents a particularly difficult challenge in searching for suitable NLO materials with wide UV transparency especially in the DUV region, large NLO coefficients, appropriate birefringence, and stable physical and chemical properties. In the past few decades, chemists and materials scientists have had many efforts toward understanding the relationship between NLO properties and crystals structures which is critical in guiding the exploration of new NLO materials. The anionic group theory, the macroscopic nonlinearity of crystal is the geometrical superposition of the microscopic second-order susceptibility of the NLO-active anionic groups, which was proposed by Chen et al., had a spectacular success in developing UV and DUV NLO crystals in borates, such as LiB3O5 (LBO), β-BaB2O4 (BBO), CsB3O5 (CBO) and CsLiB6O10 (CLBO), and SrBe2BO7 (SBBO). However, commercially available DUV NLO materials are still lacking. Currently, KBe2BO3F2 (KBBF) is still the only material to generate coherent light at wavelengths below 200 nm by direct second harmonic generation (SHG) response. But two fatal weaknesses of KBBF, a strong layer habit with respect to crystal growth and the use of highly toxic BeO, hinder its extensive application. Thus, there is an urgent demand to search for new DUV NLO materials that could overcome these demerits.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Deep-ultraviolet (DUV), nonlinear optical (NLO) materials, the key components of solid-state lasers producing DUV coherent light through a cascaded frequency conversion, have gained increasing attention owing to their versatile scientific and technological applications such as angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, laser-cooling, super-high-resolution, and semiconductor photolithography. Even though a few DUV NLO crystals have been reported in recent years, it still presents a particularly difficult challenge in searching for suitable NLO materials with wide UV transparency especially in the DUV region, large NLO coefficients, appropriate birefringence, and stable physical and chemical properties. In the past few decades, chemists and materials scientists have had many efforts toward understanding the relationship between NLO properties and crystals structures which is critical in guiding the exploration of new NLO materials. The anionic group theory, the macroscopic nonlinearity of crystal is the geometrical superposition of the microscopic second-order susceptibility of the NLO-active anionic groups, which was proposed by Chen et al., had a spectacular success in developing UV and DUV NLO crystals in borates, such as LiB3O5 (LBO), β-BaB2O4 (BBO), CsB3O5 (CBO) and CsLiB6O10 (CLBO), and SrBe2BO7 (SBBO). However, commercially available DUV NLO materials are still lacking. Currently, KBe2BO3F2 (KBBF) is still the only material to generate coherent light at wavelengths below 200 nm by direct second harmonic generation (SHG) response. But two fatal weaknesses of KBBF, a strong layer habit with respect to crystal growth and the use of highly toxic BeO, hinder its extensive application. Thus, there is an urgent demand to search for new DUV NLO materials that could overcome these demerits.

elements.content: In recent years, several beryllium-free chemical systems, such as fluorooxoborates, phosphates, carbonates, etc., have been developed as the alternative systems for searching for DUV NLO materials. Rare earth fluoride carbonates have an enormous potential for DUV optical applications for three reasons: (1) analogous to the [BO3]3– group, the planar [CO3]2– can also generate large second-order susceptibility and appropriate birefringence; (2) the inclusion of fluoride could make the absorption edge blue-shifted; (3) the compounds containing rare earth atoms usually exhibit excellent physical and chemical properties and optical properties, for example, YAl3(BO3)4 and LuAl3(BO3)4. Two alkaline rare earth fluoride carbonates Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu­(CO3)2F2, exhibiting short UV cutoff edges (<200 nm) and large SHG effects, have been successfully synthesized by Ye’s group which were proven to be potential DUV NLO materials. A few other rare earth fluoride carbonates like NaLa2(CO3)2­[F2x (CO3)1–x ]­F, Na2Yb­(CO3)­F, Na3Yb­(CO3)2F2, etc., have been reported just on synthesis and crystals structures without study of optical properties. Up to now, no systematically study has been done in exploring rare earth fluoride carbonates optical materials. The hydrothermal method is a facile synthetic route, and most carbonates have been synthesized using this method. In this work, we chose the Na2CO3–GdF3–H2O as reaction system and investigated in detail phase stability domains in subcritical hydrothermal conditions in order to guide subsequent synthesis and crystal growth of new rare earth fluoride carbonates. A series of sodium rare earth carbonates crystals NaGdCO3F2 (1), Na2GdCO3F3 (2), Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3), and Na3Gd­(CO3)3·6H2O (4) have been discovered and proved to be potential DUV optical materials. Herein the synthesis, crystal structures, thermal behaviors, spectra, and NLO properties are reported.

elements.content:
All starting materials Na2CO3 (≥99.5%),and GdF3 (99.9%) were analytical grade from commercial sources and used without further treatment.

Synthesis of NaGdCO<sub>3</sub>F<sub>2</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (0.318 g, 3 mmol) and GdF3 (0.214g, 1 mmol) were added to deionized water (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 min (pH = 12), sealed into a 23 mL Teflon autoclave, heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and then slowly cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, which is beneficial to obtain high quality crystals for single crystal structure determination. Cooling too fast may lead to twined crystal of poor quality. The products were washed with deionized water and then dried in air. Transparent stick crystals of NaGdCO3F2 shown in Figure S1a were obtained in yields of about 71% (on the basis of Gd).

Experimental Section

Synthesis

All starting materials Na2CO3 (≥99.5%),and GdF3 (99.9%) were analytical grade from commercial sources and used without further treatment.

Synthesis of NaGdCO3F2 (1)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (0.318 g, 3 mmol) and GdF3 (0.214g, 1 mmol) were added to deionized water (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 min (pH = 12), sealed into a 23 mL Teflon autoclave, heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and then slowly cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, which is beneficial to obtain high quality crystals for single crystal structure determination. Cooling too fast may lead to twined crystal of poor quality. The products were washed with deionized water and then dried in air. Transparent stick crystals of NaGdCO3F2 shown in Figure S1a were obtained in yields of about 71% (on the basis of Gd).

elements.content: Na2GdCO3F3 was hydrothermally synthesized by reactions of a mixture of Na2CO3 (0.531 g, 5 mmol), GdF3 (0.214 g, 1 mmol), and deionized water (5 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave (pH = 12) and heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The transparent products were obtained and washed with deionized water, and dried in air. The crystals shown in Figure S1b were collected in yields of about 81% (on the basis of Gd).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Na2GdCO3F3 (2)

Na2GdCO3F3 was hydrothermally synthesized by reactions of a mixture of Na2CO3 (0.531 g, 5 mmol), GdF3 (0.214 g, 1 mmol), and deionized water (5 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave (pH = 12) and heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The transparent products were obtained and washed with deionized water, and dried in air. The crystals shown in Figure S1b were collected in yields of about 81% (on the basis of Gd).

Transparent plate crystals of Na3Gd­(CO3)3 shown in Figure S1c were obtained in yields of about 34% (on the basis of Gd).

elements.content: A mixture of Na2CO3 (3.392 g, 32 mmol), GdF3(0.856g, 4 mmol) was added to the 5 mL deionized water and stirring for about 20 min. The resulting solution was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave (pH = 12), and heated at 220 °C for 6 days and then slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The colorless block crystals shown in Figure S1d were obtained in yields of about 48% (on the basis of Gd).

Synthesis of Na3Gd(CO3)3⋅6H2O (4)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (3.392 g, 32 mmol), GdF3(0.856g, 4 mmol) was added to the 5 mL deionized water and stirring for about 20 min. The resulting solution was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave (pH = 12), and heated at 220 °C for 6 days and then slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The colorless block crystals shown in Figure S1d were obtained in yields of about 48% (on the basis of Gd).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) data of NaGdCO3F2 (1), Na2GdCO3F3 (2), Na3Gd­(CO3)3(3), and Na3Gd­(CO3)3·6H2O (4) were collected at 100 K, 296(2) K, 150(2) K, and 150(2) K on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation. The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F2 using SHELX-2014. All hydrogen atoms were located geometrically or in a difference Fourier map, and refined with a riding model. All of the structures were verified using the ADDSYM algorithm from the program PLATON, and no higher symmetries were found. The values of the Flack parameters for the two acentric structures Na3Gd­(CO3)3(3) and Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O (4) are very close to zero, suggesting that the absolute structures of the titled compounds are correct. Relevant crystallographic data and details of the experimental conditions for 1, 2, 3, and 4 are summarized in . Atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement coefficients are listed in Tables S1–S4. Selected bond lengths for the four compounds are listed in Tables S5–S8.

Single Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) data of NaGdCO3F2 (1), Na2GdCO3F3 (2), Na3Gd(CO3)3(3), and Na3Gd(CO3)3⋅6H2O (4) were collected at 100 K, 296(2) K, 150(2) K, and 150(2) K on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation. The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F2 using SHELX-2014. All hydrogen atoms were located geometrically or in a difference Fourier map, and refined with a riding model. All of the structures were verified using the ADDSYM algorithm from the program PLATON, and no higher symmetries were found. The values of the Flack parameters for the two acentric structures Na3Gd(CO3)3(3) and Na3Gd(CO3)3⋅6H2O (4) are very close to zero, suggesting that the absolute structures of the titled compounds are correct. Relevant crystallographic data and details of the experimental conditions for 1, 2, 3, and 4 are summarized in . Atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement coefficients are listed in Tables S1-S4. Selected bond lengths for the four compounds are listed in Tables S5-S8.

X-ray diffraction patterns of the polycrystalline materials were obtained on a Smart lab powder X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) at room temperature in the angular range of 2θ from 5 to 55° with a scan step width of 0.02° and a fixed time of 0.2 s. The powder XRD patterns of NaGdCO3F2 (1), Na2GdCO3F3 (2), Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3), and Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O (4) show that experimental patterns are in good agreement with the calculated patterns based on the results from single-crystal XRD. (Figure S2).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a Netzsch STA 409 PC. The crystal samples (10–15 mg) were enclosed in platinum crucibles and heated from room temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under a constant flow of air gas.

Thermal Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a Netzsch STA 409 PC. The crystal samples (10-15 mg) were enclosed in platinum crucibles and heated from room temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under a constant flow of air gas.

elements.content:
The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy of the four compounds were recorded at room temperature using a PerkinElmer Lamda-950 UV/vis/NIR spectrophotometer and scanned at 200–2500 nm.

Paramagnetic Property

The magnetic behaviors of NaGdCO3F2 (1) and Na2GdCO3F3 (2) were studied at room temperature using a vibration sample magnetometer (VSM).

Second-Harmonic Generation

Powder SHG signals were measured using the method adapted from Kurtz and Perry at room temperature. Since SHG efficiencies are known to depend strongly on particle size, polycrystalline Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3) and Na3Gd­(CO3)3·6H2O (4) samples were ground and divided into the following particle size ranges: 25–45, 45–58, 58–75, 75–106, 106–150, and 150–212 μm. The measurements were performed with a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at 1064 nm for UV SHG. Microcrystalline KDP with the same particle size ranges were used as a reference.

elements.content: All the experiments were done under subcritical conditions at 220 °C, and the stability domains of Na2CO3–GdF3–H2O system are indicated in as a function of the [GdF3] concentration and the [Na+]/[Gd3+] ratio. The domain limits were visually estimated, and the mixtures of phases were found in the vicinity of the limits. From the figure, we can see that the concentration of the starting materials which refer to the concentration of [GdF3] and [Na2CO3] has an influence on the products and which were studied in our experiments. With the increasing of [Na+]/[Gd3+] ratio, the proportion of Na+ in the synthesized compounds increased until Na2CO3 was got without F– and Gd3+. Meanwhile, with the increase of the concentration of [GdF3], the ratio of F– in the products increased, but if the [Na+]/[Gd3+] ratio is high enough, F– disappeared in the products, even if we increase the concentration of [GdF3]. At low [GdF3] concentration, when 4 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 15, NaGdCO3F2 (1) exists; 15 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 20, Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3) is found, approximately. At high [GdF3] concentration, two phases exist: Na2GdCO3F3 (2) for 4 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 14, and Na3Gd­(CO3)3(H2O)6 for 12 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 19, approximately. When [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 4, no matter how high the [GdF3] concentration is, no single crystals can be synthesized. We think that the [Na+]/[Gd3+] ratio plays a decisive role in the synthesizing of rare earth fluoride carbonate, but not the concentration of [GdF3], because Na+ plays an important role of templating in the synthesizing of rare earth fluoride carbonate. Crystallization domains undergo strong evolutions with temperature. Control experiments have been done at 260 °C, and no single crystals can be synthesized at 220 °C at a low concentration of [GdF3], when 0 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 4, while mixed phases NaGdCO3F2 (1) and Na2GdCO3F3 (2) exist in the same domains. Hence, a more systematic study of phase stability domains in the rare earth fluoride carbonate–water system is needed to guide subsequent synthesis and crystal growth of fluoride carbonates.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Stability Regions of Na2CO3-GdF3-H2O System

All the experiments were done under subcritical conditions at 220 °C, and the stability domains of Na2CO3-GdF3-H2O system are indicated in  as a function of the [GdF3] concentration and the [Na+]/[Gd3+] ratio. The domain limits were visually estimated, and the mixtures of phases were found in the vicinity of the limits. From the figure, we can see that the concentration of the starting materials which refer to the concentration of [GdF3] and [Na2CO3] has an influence on the products and which were studied in our experiments. With the increasing of [Na+]/[Gd3+] ratio, the proportion of Na+ in the synthesized compounds increased until Na2CO3 was got without F- and Gd3+. Meanwhile, with the increase of the concentration of [GdF3], the ratio of F- in the products increased, but if the [Na+]/[Gd3+] ratio is high enough, F- disappeared in the products, even if we increase the concentration of [GdF3]. At low [GdF3] concentration, when 4 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 15, NaGdCO3F2 (1) exists; 15 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 20, Na3Gd(CO3)3 (3) is found, approximately. At high [GdF3] concentration, two phases exist: Na2GdCO3F3 (2) for 4 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 14, and Na3Gd(CO3)3(H2O)6 for 12 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 19, approximately. When [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 4, no matter how high the [GdF3] concentration is, no single crystals can be synthesized. We think that the [Na+]/[Gd3+] ratio plays a decisive role in the synthesizing of rare earth fluoride carbonate, but not the concentration of [GdF3], because Na+ plays an important role of templating in the synthesizing of rare earth fluoride carbonate. Crystallization domains undergo strong evolutions with temperature. Control experiments have been done at 260 °C, and no single crystals can be synthesized at 220 °C at a low concentration of [GdF3], when 0 < [Na+]/[Gd3+] < 4, while mixed phases NaGdCO3F2 (1) and Na2GdCO3F3 (2) exist in the same domains. Hence, a more systematic study of phase stability domains in the rare earth fluoride carbonate-water system is needed to guide subsequent synthesis and crystal growth of fluoride carbonates.

There are one independent Gd atom, one independent Na atom, one independent F atom, one independent C atom, and three independent O atoms in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the gadolinium atom is eight coordinated with four oxygen atoms (two O1, one O2, and one O3) and four fluorine atom (F1) and form distorted tetragonal prism polyhedron mode (b). Na+ ions are located in the cavity constructed by six Gd3+, eight F–, and four CO3 2– anions and play the role of charge balance cations.

Crystal Structure Description

Compound NaGdCO3F2 (1) crystallizes into an orthorhombic crystal system with a centrosymmetric space group of Pnma (No. 62). There are one independent Gd atom, one independent Na atom, one independent F atom, one independent C atom, and three independent O atoms in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the gadolinium atom is eight coordinated with four oxygen atoms (two O1, one O2, and one O3) and four fluorine atom (F1) and form distorted tetragonal prism polyhedron mode (b). The four coordination oxygen atoms are derived from three planar [CO3] triangles, and forming a [GdO4F4]9- complex, with the range of Gd-O bond lengths from 2.312(4) to 2.467(4) Å, Gd-F bond lengths ranging from 2.281(3) to 2.382(3) Å, and C-O bond lengths ranging from 1.272(8) to 1.286(7) Å. In 1, two Gd3+ are connected by two F- to form the [GdF2] chains, and the chains are further linked by the [CO3]2- to from the three-dimensional (3-D) dimensional framework (c,d). Na+ ions are located in the cavity constructed by six Gd3+, eight F-, and four CO3 2- anions and play the role of charge balance cations.

elements.content: Na2GdCO3F3 (2) crystallizes into an orthorhombic crystal system with a centrosymmetric space group of Pbca (No. 61). As shown in a, the gadolinium atom is surrounded by three oxygen atoms (two O3 and one O1) and six fluorine atom (two F1, two F2, and two F3), forming a capped distorted tetragonal prism polyhedron (b). Two planar [CO3] triangles provide the coordination oxygen atoms O1 and O3, and then form the [GdO3F6]9– complex, with the range of Gd–O bond lengths ranging from 2.402(2) to 2.521(3) Å, Gd–F bond lengths ranging from 2.334(2) to 2.404(2) Å, and C–O bond lengths ranging from 1.257(5) to 1.317(5) Å. As shown in d, two Gd3+ ions are bridged by three F– to form a one-dimensional (1-D) zigzag chain along the b-axis, and the chain is further connected by [CO3]2– to form the two-dimensional (2-D) [GdCO3F3]2– layer, and finally the layers are linked by Na+ to from the 3-D framework (c). There are two independent Na+ in 2, Na1+ is six coordinated with two oxygen atoms (one O2 and one O3), and four F atoms (two F1, one F2 and one F3), forming a NaO2F4 octahedron, and the Na2+ coordinates with four oxygen atoms (two O1 and two O2) and two fluorine atom (F2 and F3), forming the NaO4F2 octahedron coordination mode with Na–O bond lengths ranging from 2.288(3) to 2.508(3) Å and Na–F bond lengths ranging from 2.197(3) to 2.554(3) Å.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 crystallize into the adjacent space groups of Pnma (No. 62) and Pbca (No. 61), respectively, and comparing the molecular formula NaGdCO3F2 (1) with Na2GdCO3F3 (2), one extra NaF molecule exists in the latter, which results in the structure similarity and the discrepancy of the two compounds. The basic construction units in both 1 and 2 are channels constructed of six Gd3+ bridged by F– and [CO3]2– with the diameter of about 19.3 × 7.7 Å2, 6.8 × 6.2 Å2, respectively (d and d). The cavities are filled with different Na+ ions, and the additional Na+ ions in 2 located near the edge of the channels increases the steric hindrance and shrink the channels. Besides the number of bridged F– ions with Gd3+, the connecting mode between Na+ and CO3 2– is also different, Na+ and CO3 2– link to the Na2CO3 chain in compound 1 and form Na2CO3 layer in compound 2 (e and e). Both the differences ascribe to the additional NaF in 2.

elements.content: Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3) crystallizes into an orthorhombic crystal system with a noncentrosymmetric space group of Ama2 (No. 40). One independent Gd atom, three independent Na atoms, two independent C atoms, and six independent O atoms are contained in the asymmetric unit. The Gd3+ ion is nine coordinated with nine oxygen atoms derived from six [CO3]2– triangles which can be divided into two types. Each [CO3]2– provides two bridge oxygen atoms in the first type and one bridge oxygen in the other type (a,b). The Gd–O bond lengths range from 2.391(4) to 2.504(4) Å and C–O bond lengths from 1.267(6) to 1.317(6) Å. There are three independent Na+ ions in compound 3, and the coordination number with oxygen atoms are eight, nine, and six from Na1 to Na3, forming the polyhedra of distorted tetragonal prism, capped distorted tetragonal prism and triangular prism, and with the range of Na–O bond lengths from 2.394(3) to 2.606(12) Å. Similar to compounds 1 and 2, Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3) also shows a 3-D framework made up of alternately stacked layers of [Na­(CO3)2]∞ and [Na2Gd­(CO3)2]∞ along the c axis (c). All the [CO3] triangles in the [Na­(CO3)2]∞ layer have two orientations which are almost vertical, and [CO3]2– is completely parallel in each orientation (d). Similarly, all the [CO3]2– planar triangles in the other [Na2Gd­(CO3)2]∞ layer arrange in the same direction in the bc plane (e), and both the layers give cooperative contribution to the relatively strong SHG effect of 3.

elements.content: Crystal Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O (4) crystallizes into a hexagonal crystal system with an acentric space group of P63 (No. 173). As shown in a, the Gd3+ is surrounded by nine oxygen atoms (three O1, three O3, and three O4) to form a {GdO9} tricapped trigonal prism polyhedron with the bond lengths of Gd–O ranging from 2.404(11) to 2.524(8) Å and C–O bond lengths from 1.282(14) to 1.308(15) Å (b). The coordination oxygen atoms can be divided into two types, O3 and O4 derived from one [CO3]2– triangle, and O1 from water molecules. Six [Gd­(CO3)3­(H2O)3]3– complexes are connected by Na+ to form a hexagon wheel with a channel size of 8.90 Å, and wheels are further connected by Na+ to form a 2-D layer in the ab plane and then linked by Na+ along the c axis to form a 3-D framework (c,d). Only coordination water molecules are filled in the cavity of the wheels. As mentioned above in the compound 4, Gd3+ coordinates with three [CO3]2– triangles, although these three [CO3]2– are in parallel with themselves in the 3-D framework, they have different orientation compared with the others, which cause 4 a moderate SHG effect.

elements.content: Fluoride-free compounds 3 and 4 crystallize into noncentrosymmetric space groups of Ama2 and P63, both the Gd3+ in 3 and 4 are nine coordinated with oxygen atoms and six of them are provided by three [CO3]2– triangles, and each [CO3]2– provides two coordination oxygen atoms. The rest three are from three [CO3]2– triangles or three H2O molecules, respectively, so no matter [CO3]2– in 3 or H2O in 4 are one coordinated with one Gd3+ ion. The coordination ability of [CO3]2– is stronger than H2O, and meanwhile the steric hindrance of H2O is smaller, so 4 crystallizes with a higher symmetry.

The rest three are from three [CO3]2- triangles or three H2O molecules, respectively, so no matter [CO3]2- in 3 or H2O in 4 are one coordinated with one Gd3+ ion. The coordination ability of [CO3]2- is stronger than H2O, and meanwhile the steric hindrance of H2O is smaller, so 4 crystallizes with a higher symmetry.

elements.content: The bond valence sums for the four compounds are calculated using the following formula, V i = ∑ j S i j = ∑ j exp { ( r 0 − r i j ) / B } where S ij is the bond valence associated with the bond length r ij , bond valence parameters r 0, and empirically determined parameter B (usually 0.37). The calculated bond valence for Na, Gd, C, O, and F atoms are summarized in Tables S1–S4, respectively, and the results indicate that the oxidation states of Na, Gd, C, O, and F atoms in NaGdCO3F2 (1), Na2GdCO3F3 (2), Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3), and Na3Gd­(CO3)3·6H2O (4) are +1, + 3, + 4, −2, and −1, respectively.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of compounds 1–4 are shown in Figure S3. The TGA curve shows that NaGdCO3F2 (1) is stable up to 400 °C and exhibits one step weight loss stage in the range of 400–600 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 16.8% (calculated value 15.8%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is NaGdCO3F2 → GdOF + NaF + CO2 (g). Na2GdCO3F3 (2) reveals one step weight loss stage in the range of 350–570 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 13.9% (calculated value 13.7%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is Na2GdCO3F3 → GdOF + 2NaF + CO2 (g). Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3) is stable up to 420 °C and undergoes one step weight loss stage in the range of 420–630 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 16.47% (calculated value 16.24%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is Na3Gd­(CO3)3→ 0.5Gd2O3 + 1.5Na2CO3 + 1.5CO2 (g). The TG curve of Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O (4) shows two major weight loss stages in the regions about 50–400 °C and 400–800 °C, The first weight loss is 18.72% assigned to the release of six coordination water molecules (calcd 21.00%), followed by the loss of 13.28% corresponding to the decomposition of carbonate groups (calcd 12.8%). The decomposition reaction is Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O → 0.5Gd2O3 + 1.5Na2CO3 + 1.5CO2 (g) + 6H2O. The powder XRD patterns for the decomposition products of the four titled compounds have been measured, which are in accordance with decomposition reactions (Figure S4).

Thermal Properties

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of compounds 1-4 are shown in Figure S3. The TGA curve shows that NaGdCO3F2 (1) is stable up to 400 °C and exhibits one step weight loss stage in the range of 400-600 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 16.8% (calculated value 15.8%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. Na2GdCO3F3 (2) reveals one step weight loss stage in the range of 350-570 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 13.9% (calculated value 13.7%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is Na2GdCO3F3 → GdOF + 2NaF + CO2 (g). Na3Gd(CO3)3 (3) is stable up to 420 °C and undergoes one step weight loss stage in the range of 420-630 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 16.47% (calculated value 16.24%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is Na3Gd(CO3)3→ 0.5Gd2O3 + 1.5Na2CO3 + 1.5CO2 (g). The TG curve of Na3Gd(CO3)3⋅6H2O (4) shows two major weight loss stages in the regions about 50-400 °C and 400-800 °C, The first weight loss is 18.72% assigned to the release of six coordination water molecules (calcd 21.00%), followed by the loss of 13.28% corresponding to the decomposition of carbonate groups (calcd 12.8%). elements.content: The IR spectra of four compounds were measured (Figure S5). The obvious C–O vibrations were observed between 1600–650 cm–1. The strong broad bands appeared in the range of 1558–1377 cm–1 belong to the stretching ν­(C–O) vibrations. The medium bands in the range of 870–839 cm–1 can be assigned to the out-of-plane vibrations of δ­(OCO), and the bending vibration of δ­(OCO) appears as a medium-weak band at 762–685 cm–1, which is in agreement with the reported carbonates.

Optical Properties

The IR spectra of four compounds were measured (Figure S5). The obvious C-O vibrations were observed between 1600-650 cm-1. The strong broad bands appeared in the range of 1558-1377 cm-1 belong to the stretching ν(C-O) vibrations. The medium bands in the range of 870-839 cm-1 can be assigned to the out-of-plane vibrations of δ(OCO), and the bending vibration of δ(OCO) appears as a medium-weak band at 762-685 cm-1, which is in agreement with the reported carbonates.

elements.content: The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were collected for compounds 1–4, and the absorption (K/S) data were calculated from the following Kubelka–Munk function: F ( R ) = ( 1 − R ) 2 2 R = K S In this function, R is the reflectance, K is the absorption, and S is the scattering. In the (K/S) versus E plots, extrapolating the linear part of the rising curve to zero provides the onset of absorption. No obvious absorption peak was observed in the range of 200–2500 nm, indicating that all four compounds are potentially deep-ultraviolet optical crystals ().

elements.content: The gadolinium atom, which has seven unpaired electrons in its outer layer, possesses large magnetic moments, symmetrical electronic ground state, and long electron relaxation time, has been frequently used in synthesizing magnetism materials. As mentioned above, we have synthesized four Gd3+ contained rare earth fluoride carbonates, which may be potential magnetism materials. Hence, we chose compounds NaGdCO3F2 (1) and Na2GdCO3F3 (2) among them for further magnetism measurement with an applied magnetic field. As shown in , both samples reveal small magnetization which varies lineally with respect to external magnetic field, and the hysteresis loops of 1 and 2 were observed at room temperature (300 K). Meanwhile we can see that both two samples present benign paramagnetism in the magnetic range of −80–80 kOe, and moreover, the observed maximum magnetization of 1 is 6.62 emu/g, while 2 is 5.79 emu/g.
elements.clean_text:
Paramagnetic Properties

The gadolinium atom, which has seven unpaired electrons in its outer layer, possesses large magnetic moments, symmetrical electronic ground state, and long electron relaxation time, has been frequently used in synthesizing magnetism materials. As mentioned above, we have synthesized four Gd3+ contained rare earth fluoride carbonates, which may be potential magnetism materials. Hence, we chose compounds NaGdCO3F2 (1) and Na2GdCO3F3 (2) among them for further magnetism measurement with an applied magnetic field. As shown in , both samples reveal small magnetization which varies lineally with respect to external magnetic field, and the hysteresis loops of 1 and 2 were observed at room temperature (300 K). Meanwhile we can see that both two samples present benign paramagnetism in the magnetic range of -80-80 kOe, and moreover, the observed maximum magnetization of 1 is 6.62 emu/g, while 2 is 5.79 emu/g.

elements.content: Among the four compounds, Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3) and Na3Gd­(CO3)3·6H2O (4) are non-centrosymmetric; therefore, the SHG response of them were measured on a 1064 nm Q-switch laser using the sieved power samples by the Kurtz–Perry method. A KDP sample was used as the reference and the second-harmonic signals were found to be 3 × KDP and 2 × KDP for 3 and 4. As shown in , the intensity of the SHG signals of the two compounds increase gradually with the increasing of the sample size, and it tends to be constant from 150 μm, which indicates that the compounds 3 and 4 are type I phase-matchable.
elements.clean_text:
Nonlinear Optical (NLO) Properties

Among the four compounds, Na3Gd(CO3)3 (3) and Na3Gd(CO3)3⋅6H2O (4) are non-centrosymmetric; therefore, the SHG response of them were measured on a 1064 nm Q-switch laser using the sieved power samples by the Kurtz-Perry method. A KDP sample was used as the reference and the second-harmonic signals were found to be 3 × KDP and 2 × KDP for 3 and 4. As shown in , the intensity of the SHG signals of the two compounds increase gradually with the increasing of the sample size, and it tends to be constant from 150 μm, which indicates that the compounds 3 and 4 are type I phase-matchable.

elements.content: Owing to the high symmetry of the [CO3] group, the macroscopic second-order susceptibility of NLO carbonates materials could be simplified to according to the anionic group theory, d = F × ( n / V ) × C × β 111 ( [ CO 3 ] ) where F is the correction factor of the localized field; n is the number of anionic groups in a unit cell, V is the volume of the unit cell; C is the structural criterion, and β111([CO3]) is the nonvanishing second-order susceptibility. So from this equation, the macroscopic NLO coefficient is proportional to the density of the [CO3] group (n/V) and the structural criterion (C). The NLO coefficients for compounds 1, 2, 3, and 4 and some reported carbonates NLO materials were calculated in order to gain further insight of the SHG effects as determined by the density of NLO-active groups and the arrangement of the NLO-active groups (). According to previous used computing method, the calculated value of C factor for compounds 1, 2, 3, and 4 are 0, 0, 0.641, and 0.665, respectively. A parallel orientation of the CO3 layers leads to high structural criterion like 1.00 in KSrCO3F, while the antiparallel orientation of the CO3 layers gives centrosymmetry, and the SHG effect is canceled such as NaGdCO3F2 and Na2GdCO3F3. As shown in , the largest SHG coefficient did not come from the largest density of the [CO3]2– group or the largest structural criterion (C). In KSrCO3F, a relatively small density of the [CO3]2– group leads to a moderate SHG coefficient though the [CO3] triangles are all exactly parallel to each other, giving the largest C (1.00). In Na3Gd­(CO3)3, a relatively small structural criterion leads to moderate SHG coefficient though the density of the [CO3]2– group is largest, while a relatively large density of the [CO3]2– group and a relatively large structural criterion (C) lead to a large SHG coefficient in Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu­(CO3)2F2. Thus, how to balance the density of NLO-active groups and the structural criterion C is very important for exploring new NLO materials.

It is generally accepted that the fundamental attributes of a phase are defined by the crystal structure more than the chemical composition; thus the arrangement of fundamental building blocks (FBB) or chemical units has a profound influence on physical and chemical properties of the phase. Understanding the relationship between crystals structures and properties is critical for guiding the exploration of new materials. Ye’s group and Halasyamani’s group has made many efforts toward understanding the relationship between NLO properties and NCS crystals structures in fluoride carbonates to develop novel DUV NLO materials. And a series of mixed alkali metal and alkaline earth metal fluoride carbonates as potential deep-ultraviolet NLO materials have been discovered. Ye’s group focused on effect of radius ratio of cations in AMCO3F-type (A represents the alkali metal elements, M represents alkaline earth or IIB metal elements) compounds. Halasyamani’s group studied the SHG efficiency vs SAMD vs cation variance through examination of the known SHG active AMCO3F (A = alkali metal, M = alkaline earth metal, Zn, Cd, or Pb) materials to draw a conclusion: on average, smaller A cations and larger M cations result in increased SHG efficiencies. On the basis of the research work of Ye’s group and Halasyamani’s group, we discussed how to arrange carbonate and fluoride ions in crystals structures to get excellent optical properties in rare earth carbonates in this work. The optical properties of NLO crystals are mainly manifested in two aspects: the nonlinear optical coefficient and the birefringence. The nonlinear optical coefficient influences the conversion efficiency of laser, and the birefringence determines the capability of phase matching in the particular spectral region. In fluoride carbonates, fluoride ions show weak and isotropic polarizability (α = 0.86 × 10–24cm3), while (CO3)2– ions exhibit large and anisotropic polarizability (α|| = 4.2 × 10–24 cm3 and α⊥ = 3.18 × 10–24 cm3). Such a huge difference between both ions may lead to interesting optical properties such as appropriate birefringence and strong SHG. How to arrange carbonate and fluoride ions in suitable structures to make them cooperate with each other remains a challenge. [CO3] groups with the planar triangular structure are the fundamental building blocks in carbonates which do not polymerize due to having a low bond valence. Thus, crystal structures of carbonate phases tend to form layered topology with the planar [CO3] groups either flat-lying or standing-on-edge with respect to the overall structural layering which may be influenced by the addition of another anion, F–. As mentioned previously, the macroscopic NLO coefficient of carbonates is decided by density of the [CO3] groups and the structural criterion. The birefringence, another important optical property, increases with an increasing degree of anisotropy in polarizability. The perpendicular arrangement of carbonate groups to the structure layering will make the anisotropy decrease. Hence, keeping a dense arrangement of flat-lying [CO3] groups in carbonates is the best strategy. In the carbonates compounds with layer structures such as KZnCO3F, KMgCO3F, CsCaCO3F, RbSrCO3F, KZnCO3F, K2RbCO3F, Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2, Na3Gd­(CO3)3, Na3Ce2(CO3)4F, etc., though they show different crystal structures, the main structure units MO n F m (n = 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9; m = 0, 1, 2) are still strongly correlated, which are shown in . All MO n F m polyhedra share their equatorial oxygen atoms to connect with circumambient planar [CO3] groups to form MO n -AO3 layers which are connected by the F atoms situating at the apical positions (a–e,h). All the [CO3] groups are flat-lying. When all F atoms are replaced by O atoms, the MO n F m polyhedra turn to the MO n polyhedra which connect to more [CO3] groups with partial [CO3] groups standing-on-edge. In MO n F m polyhedral, the steric force of the apical F atoms forces all the O atoms to orient in a layer style to make the [CO3] groups flat-lying. The counter-cation coordination sphere of the [CO3] groups plays a vital role in the structural arrangement of the closest neighboring anions groups in the crystal. In the MO n F m polyhedral, when n is on a multiple of 3 (n = 3, 6, 9), all the M–O bonds point to three different [CO3] groups and force them to align in the same orientation (a,d,h) to give the largest contribution (100%) to the NLO affect, whereas when n is not on a multiple of 3 (n = 4, 5, 8), parts of the [CO3] groups are nearly antiparallel with others to cancel out their contributions (b,c,e,f). Following the successful synthesizing of a series of NCS carbonates compounds, we can draw the following conclusion to design new NCS carbonates with large NLO coefficients and suitable birefringence: First, select a countercation with high coordination number like alkaline earth metal ions with big radius or rare earth metal ions which could form a MO n F m polyhedral such as GdO9, SrO6F2, and EuO9F. Trying best to keep more O and less F is helpful for connecting with more [CO3] groups to get a high density of anionic groups. Especially, those cations with an equatorial plane containing O atoms with a number of a multiple of 3 like SrO6F2 and EuO9F could force the [CO3] groups to form 2-D MO n -CO3 layers for appropriate birefringence. Second, choosing another suitable cation as charge-balance cation with suitable coordinated atoms in an eclipse style results in steric force to arrange the adjacent MO n -AO3 layers coparallel to give a maximum contribution to the SHG effect. Thus, the synergistic effect of countercations and balance charge cations with a suitable size could force the [CO3] groups in a dense flat-lying arrangement to get excellent properties, which may be a particularly useful approach for designing new SHG compounds in carbonate families.

elements.content: Systematic research on phase stability regions in a Na2CO3–GdF3–H2O system has been investigated in detail in subcritical hydrothermal conditions to explore potential deep-ultraviolet optical materials for the first time. A new series of sodium-rare earth carbonate crystals NaGdCO3F2 (1), Na2GdCO3F3 (2), Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3), and Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O (4) have been successfully synthesized. Compounds 1 and 2 crystallize in CS space groups Pnma and Pbca, and compounds 3 and 4 in NCS space groups Ama2 and P63, respectively. All four carbonates compounds exhibit a 3-D structure that is composed of GdO m F n , NaO x polyhedral, and CO3 groups. Second harmonic generation studies indicated that 3 and 4 have relatively strong SHG responses of approximately 3 and 2 times that of KDP, respectively. The result from the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy study of the powder samples indicated that the short-wavelength absorption edge of the four compounds was below 200 nm, suggesting that these crystals are potential deep-ultraviolet optical crystals materials. Furthermore, the discovery of a new series of rare earth carbonates enriches the family of carbonates as deep-ultraviolet optical materials, and some rules from our studies of the relationship between the arrangement of planar CO3 groups and optical properties will be valuable for designing new NLO materials in other carbonate families.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Systematic research on phase stability regions in a Na2CO3-GdF3-H2O system has been investigated in detail in subcritical hydrothermal conditions to explore potential deep-ultraviolet optical materials for the first time. A new series of sodium-rare earth carbonate crystals NaGdCO3F2 (1), Na2GdCO3F3 (2), Na3Gd(CO3)3 (3), and Na3Gd(CO3)3⋅6H2O (4) have been successfully synthesized. Compounds 1 and 2 crystallize in CS space groups Pnma and Pbca, and compounds 3 and 4 in NCS space groups Ama2 and P63, respectively. All four carbonates compounds exhibit a 3-D structure that is composed of GdO m F n , NaO x  polyhedral, and CO3 groups. Second harmonic generation studies indicated that 3 and 4 have relatively strong SHG responses of approximately 3 and 2 times that of KDP, respectively. The result from the UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy study of the powder samples indicated that the short-wavelength absorption edge of the four compounds was below 200 nm, suggesting that these crystals are potential deep-ultraviolet optical crystals materials. Furthermore, the discovery of a new series of rare earth carbonates enriches the family of carbonates as deep-ultraviolet optical materials, and some rules from our studies of the relationship between the arrangement of planar CO3 groups and optical properties will be valuable for designing new NLO materials in other carbonate families.

cln_elements.content:
All starting materials Na2CO3 (≥99.5%),and GdF3 (99.9%) were analytical grade from commercial sources and used without further treatment.

Synthesis of NaGdCO<sub>3</sub>F<sub>2</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (0.318 g, 3 mmol) and GdF3 (0.214g, 1 mmol) were added to deionized water (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 min (pH = 12), sealed into a 23 mL Teflon autoclave, heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and then slowly cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, which is beneficial to obtain high quality crystals for single crystal structure determination. Cooling too fast may lead to twined crystal of poor quality. The products were washed with deionized water and then dried in air. Transparent stick crystals of NaGdCO3F2 shown in Figure S1a were obtained in yields of about 71% (on the basis of Gd).

Synthesis of Na<sub>2</sub>GdCO<sub>3</sub>F<sub>3</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Na2GdCO3F3 was hydrothermally synthesized by reactions of a mixture of Na2CO3 (0.531 g, 5 mmol), GdF3 (0.214 g, 1 mmol), and deionized water (5 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave (pH = 12) and heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The transparent products were obtained and washed with deionized water, and dried in air. The crystals shown in Figure S1b were collected in yields of about 81% (on the basis of Gd).

Synthesis of Na<sub>3</sub>Gd­(CO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (0.424 g, 4 mmol), GdF3 (0.107 g, 0.5 mmol), and deionized water (5 mL) with a pH value about 12 was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL), heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and then slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. Transparent plate crystals of Na3Gd­(CO3)3 shown in Figure S1c were obtained in yields of about 34% (on the basis of Gd).

Synthesis of Na<sub>3</sub>Gd­(CO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (3.392 g, 32 mmol), GdF3(0.856g, 4 mmol) was added to the 5 mL deionized water and stirring for about 20 min. The resulting solution was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave (pH = 12), and heated at 220 °C for 6 days and then slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The colorless block crystals shown in Figure S1d were obtained in yields of about 48% (on the basis of Gd).

Experimental Section

Synthesis

All starting materials Na2CO3 (≥99.5%),and GdF3 (99.9%) were analytical grade from commercial sources and used without further treatment.

Synthesis of NaGdCO3F2 (1)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (0.318 g, 3 mmol) and GdF3 (0.214g, 1 mmol) were added to deionized water (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 min (pH = 12), sealed into a 23 mL Teflon autoclave, heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and then slowly cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, which is beneficial to obtain high quality crystals for single crystal structure determination. Cooling too fast may lead to twined crystal of poor quality. The products were washed with deionized water and then dried in air. Transparent stick crystals of NaGdCO3F2 shown in Figure S1a were obtained in yields of about 71% (on the basis of Gd).

Synthesis of Na2GdCO3F3 (2)

Na2GdCO3F3 was hydrothermally synthesized by reactions of a mixture of Na2CO3 (0.531 g, 5 mmol), GdF3 (0.214 g, 1 mmol), and deionized water (5 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave (pH = 12) and heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The transparent products were obtained and washed with deionized water, and dried in air. The crystals shown in Figure S1b were collected in yields of about 81% (on the basis of Gd).

Synthesis of Na3Gd(CO3)3 (3)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (0.424 g, 4 mmol), GdF3 (0.107 g, 0.5 mmol), and deionized water (5 mL) with a pH value about 12 was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL), heated at 220 °C for 6 days, and then slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. Transparent plate crystals of Na3Gd(CO3)3 shown in Figure S1c were obtained in yields of about 34% (on the basis of Gd).

Synthesis of Na3Gd(CO3)3⋅6H2O (4)

A mixture of Na2CO3 (3.392 g, 32 mmol), GdF3(0.856g, 4 mmol) was added to the 5 mL deionized water and stirring for about 20 min. The resulting solution was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave (pH = 12), and heated at 220 °C for 6 days and then slow cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The colorless block crystals shown in Figure S1d were obtained in yields of about 48% (on the basis of Gd).

cln_elements.content:
The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of compounds 1–4 are shown in Figure S3. The TGA curve shows that NaGdCO3F2 (1) is stable up to 400 °C and exhibits one step weight loss stage in the range of 400–600 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 16.8% (calculated value 15.8%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is NaGdCO3F2 → GdOF + NaF + CO2 (g). Na2GdCO3F3 (2) reveals one step weight loss stage in the range of 350–570 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 13.9% (calculated value 13.7%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is Na2GdCO3F3 → GdOF + 2NaF + CO2 (g). Na3Gd­(CO3)3 (3) is stable up to 420 °C and undergoes one step weight loss stage in the range of 420–630 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 16.47% (calculated value 16.24%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is Na3Gd­(CO3)3→ 0.5Gd2O3 + 1.5Na2CO3 + 1.5CO2 (g). The TG curve of Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O (4) shows two major weight loss stages in the regions about 50–400 °C and 400–800 °C, The first weight loss is 18.72% assigned to the release of six coordination water molecules (calcd 21.00%), followed by the loss of 13.28% corresponding to the decomposition of carbonate groups (calcd 12.8%). The decomposition reaction is Na3Gd­(CO3)3­·6H2O → 0.5Gd2O3 + 1.5Na2CO3 + 1.5CO2 (g) + 6H2O. The powder XRD patterns for the decomposition products of the four titled compounds have been measured, which are in accordance with decomposition reactions (Figure S4).

Paramagnetic Properties

The gadolinium atom, which has seven unpaired electrons in its outer layer, possesses large magnetic moments, symmetrical electronic ground state, and long electron relaxation time, has been frequently used in synthesizing magnetism materials. As mentioned above, we have synthesized four Gd3+ contained rare earth fluoride carbonates, which may be potential magnetism materials. Hence, we chose compounds NaGdCO3F2 (1) and Na2GdCO3F3 (2) among them for further magnetism measurement with an applied magnetic field. As shown in , both samples reveal small magnetization which varies lineally with respect to external magnetic field, and the hysteresis loops of 1 and 2 were observed at room temperature (300 K). Meanwhile we can see that both two samples present benign paramagnetism in the magnetic range of −80–80 kOe, and moreover, the observed maximum magnetization of 1 is 6.62 emu/g, while 2 is 5.79 emu/g.

Na2GdCO3F3 (2) reveals one step weight loss stage in the range of 350-570 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 13.9% (calculated value 13.7%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is Na2GdCO3F3 → GdOF + 2NaF + CO2 (g). Na3Gd(CO3)3 (3) is stable up to 420 °C and undergoes one step weight loss stage in the range of 420-630 °C under air atmosphere, resulting in a total weight loss of about 16.47% (calculated value 16.24%) corresponding to decomposition of carbonate groups. The decomposition reaction is Na3Gd(CO3)3⋅6H2O → 0.5Gd2O3 + 1.5Na2CO3 + 1.5CO2 (g) + 6H2O. The powder XRD patterns for the decomposition products of the four titled compounds have been measured, which are in accordance with decomposition reactions (Figure S4).

The gadolinium atom, which has seven unpaired electrons in its outer layer, possesses large magnetic moments, symmetrical electronic ground state, and long electron relaxation time, has been frequently used in synthesizing magnetism materials.
